results.title: Corey Lewandowski Was Fired in 2016. Why Is He Back at Trump’s Side?
results.abstract: Donald Trump often finds comfort in Mr. Lewandowski’s feisty instincts and off-color humor. But some Trump aides worry about his penchant for making his own headlines.

multimedia.caption: Corey Lewandowski at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee in July. He has always found a way to regain Mr. Trump’s trust and tunnel his way back in.
multimedia.copyright: Todd Heisler/The New York Times

results.title: Meta Plans to Bar the Russian TV Network RT From Its Apps
results.abstract: The Facebook and Instagram owner said it would bar Russian media outlets including RT, which the U.S. has accused of acting as an intelligence arm.

des_facet: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

results.title: Suspect Never Took a Shot at Trump but Hid Undetected for 12 Hours
results.abstract: Ryan W. Routh was charged with two federal gun crimes a day after Secret Service agents fired on him as he pointed a rifle toward the golf course where former President Donald Trump was playing.
results.byline: By Adam Goldman and Glenn Thrush
org_facet: Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives

results.title: Secret Service Admits Not Searching Golf Course Perimeter, Drawing New Scrutiny
results.abstract: The agency’s acting director, Ronald L. Rowe Jr., praised his agents’ actions but conceded that there was no sweep of the course at Donald Trump’s club that a gunman had staked out.

multimedia.caption: Ronald L. Rowe Jr., the Secret Service’s acting director, said that in order to handle an increasingly challenging threat environment, the agency would need Congress to provide more funding.

results.title: Tense Teamsters Meeting With Harris Ends With an Endorsement Still Dangling

results.title: Black Voters Matter Says It Will Spend $15 Million in Battleground States
results.abstract: The nonpartisan group will mount a voter mobilization effort that includes radio ads, billboards and on-the-ground canvassing operations, with a focus on early voting.

multimedia.caption: Voting during the presidential primary in Michigan in February. A national organization focused on mobilizing Black voters announced on Monday it would spend at least $15 million in battleground states, including Michigan, this year.

results.abstract: The book, “Ukraine’s Unwinnable War,” calls the former president a “buffoon” and vents anger over Iran, but saves its most vitriolic language for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

results.title: Trump, Using Harsh Language, Urges Democrats to Tone Down Theirs
results.abstract: The authorities have not provided information about the gunman’s motive in the apparent assassination attempt on Sunday, yet former President Donald J. Trump, who has his own history of using violent language, sought to blame Democrats.
results.byline: By Michael Gold and Maggie Astor

multimedia.caption: Former President Donald J. Trump during a campaign rally in Mosinee, Wis., earlier this month. Mr. Trump blamed Democrats’ “inflammatory language” for motivating a gunman arrested at one of his golf courses on Sunday.

results.title: Trump, Outrage and the Modern Era of Political Violence
results.abstract: The latest apparent assassination attempt against the former president indicates how much the American political landscape has been shaped by anger stirred by him and against him.

results.title: In Senate, Democrats Hope 2024 Will Be a Record Year for Black Women
results.abstract: With Vice President Kamala Harris at the top of the ticket and Senate seats open, Democrats could for the first time send two Black women to the chamber.

multimedia.caption: Representative Lisa Blunt Rochester, a Senate candidate in Delaware, speaking at the Democratic National Convention last month. “To know that you’re going to be in a place and belong” was invaluable, she said on Friday.

results.title: Big Energy Issue in Pennsylvania Is Low Natural Gas Prices. Not Fracking.
results.abstract: Energy businesses and farmers in western Pennsylvania are struggling because of prices, an issue that has not figured prominently in the campaigns of Donald J. Trump and Kamala Harris.

multimedia.caption: Natural gas equipment in Washington County, Pa. For many voters in southwestern Pennsylvania, the question is how to build the infrastructure to get natural gas to places where it will fetch higher prices.
